children.value: Barrett Reduction is an optimization algorithm used in modular arithmetic calculations (finding remainders) that avoids expensive division operations. Its basic concept is quite straightforward.
When calculating the remainder r of

children.html: a mod Na \bmod NamodN

children.value: (a modulo N), the conventional approach is to first compute the quotient

children.html: q=a÷Nq = a \div Nq=a÷N
r=a−q×Nr = a - q \times Nr=a−q×N

children.value: However, computing q requires a division operation, which is computationally expensive for CPUs. Barrett Reduction avoids this division by introducing a pre-computed constant.

children.html: R=2kR = 2^kR=2k
R>NR > NR>N
μ=⌊R/N⌋\mu = \lfloor R / N \rfloorμ=⌊R/N⌋
⌊⌋\lfloor \rfloor⌊⌋
a mod Na \bmod NamodN
q=⌊(a×μ)/R⌋q = \lfloor(a \times \mu) / R\rfloorq=⌊(a×μ)/R⌋
r=a−q×Nr = a - q \times Nr=a−q×N
r≥Nr \geq Nr≥N
r=r−Nr = r - Nr=r−N

children.value: The key optimization here is that since R is a power of 2,

children.html: (a×μ)/R(a \times \mu) / R(a×μ)/R

children.value: can be implemented through a simple bit shift operation:

children.html: q=(a×μ)≫kq = (a \times \mu) \gg kq=(a×μ)≫k

children.value: For a fixed finite field, N is typically constant, so

children.html: μ\muμ

children.value: can also be pre-computed and stored.
This method may result in q being slightly smaller than the actual quotient because

children.html: μ\muμ
R/NR/NR/N

children.value: (due to the floor function). This is why we need to check if r is less than N after calculating

children.html: r=a−q×Nr = a - q \times Nr=a−q×N

children.value: , and subtract N again if r is greater than or equal to N.
Regarding the number of times N needs to be subtracted in the worst case:
The upper bound of the error can be proven to be 2. That is, the calculated r can be at most 2N larger than the actual remainder.
Therefore, at most two subtractions of N are needed to obtain the correct remainder.
Avoids expensive division operations, replacing them with multiplication and bit shift operations.

children.html: μ\muμ

children.value: can be pre-computed, further improving efficiency.
Even in the worst case, only a finite number (at most two) of additional subtractions are needed.

a/Na/Na/N

q=⌊(a×μ)/R⌋q = \lfloor(a \times \mu) / R\rfloorq=⌊(a×μ)/R⌋

q=⌊(a×μ)/R⌋≤⌊(a×(R/N))/R⌋(since μ≤R/N)=⌊a/N⌋=q′\begin{aligned} q &= \lfloor(a \times \mu) / R\rfloor \\ &\leq \lfloor(a \times (R/N)) / R\rfloor \quad \text{(since } \mu \leq R/N\text{)} \\ &= \lfloor a / N \rfloor \\ &= q' \end{aligned}q​=⌊(a×μ)/R⌋≤⌊(a×(R/N))/R⌋(since μ≤R/N)=⌊a/N⌋=q′​

q=⌊(a×μ)/R⌋>⌊(a×(R/N−1))/R⌋(since μ>R/N−1)=⌊a/N−a/R⌋\begin{aligned} q &= \lfloor(a \times \mu) / R\rfloor \\ &> \lfloor(a \times (R/N - 1)) / R\rfloor \quad \text{(since } \mu > R/N - 1\text{)} \\ &= \lfloor a/N - a/R \rfloor \end{aligned}q​=⌊(a×μ)/R⌋>⌊(a×(R/N−1))/R⌋(since μ>R/N−1)=⌊a/N−a/R⌋​
